story.storybody:
Direction: Sajid-Farhad
Cast: Akshay Kumar, Riteish Deshmukh, Abhishek Bachchan, Jacqueline Fernandez, Lisa Haydon, Nargis Fakhri, Boman Irani, Jackie Shroff, Chunkey Pandey

Ratings: (0.5/5)

"Apne, apne maal ke paas jaao." That's Sandy (Akshay Kumar) telling Bunty (Abhishek Bachchan) and Teddy (Riteish Deshmukh) to go back to their respective, rightful female partners. It shouldn't be a surprise that Housefull 3 treats its female protagonists as objects. After all what's love got to do in a loud, deplorable comedy? The latest in the Housefull franchise, started by the now infamous Sajid Khan (he of Himmatwala and Humshakals), and offensively carried on by writer-director duo Sajid-Farhad is not just guilty of misogyny but is also disparaging of physically disabled and coloured people.

ALSO READ: Housefull 3 Movie Review

ALSO READ: We make films for public and not critics, says director duo Sajid-Farhad

Ganga (Jacqueline Fernandez), Jamuna (Lisa Haydon) and Saraswati (Nargis Fakhri) are sisters who've fallen hard for three "losers". One of them, in a rare, groundbreaking moment of commonsense in the film, asks why they're drawn to these men. The answer is apt: "because we're crazy" (we'll just ignore the "about them"). Sajid-Farhad, frequent collaborators of Rohit Shetty, in a now all-too-familiar trope of their oeuvre make the ladies give Hindi translations of English phrases throughout the film. It's supposed to be funny because three Bollywood actresses who are not the most proficient in Hindi are delivering these lines. That's all that they are supposed to be - objects of desire who will openly flaunt their bodies to food (this despite living in a mansion) and be daft.  

Teddy is a race car driver, Bunty a rapper and Sandy a football player who can't make the team because of racism. The irony then that the only black people are three housemaids. Sandy also has an alter ego, Sandi, which surfaces whenever the word "Indian" is uttered; it sees him become a lecherous and loony man. The three men pretend to have a handicap - Teddy can't see, Bunty can't speak and Sandy can't walk - so that their girlfriends' father (Boman Irani) doesn't die because of what is a fabricated curse. Jackie Shroff, the lucky guy with the least screen time, is Mumbai gangster wants his daughters to be wedded to "normal" guys; because you know physically disabled people are not normal human beings.  
 
Everything about Housefull 3 screams for attention. It's as if its makers want you to know that they have spent a lot on the actresses' make-up and skimpy wardrobe, the locations and the ghastly songs with innumerable extras. The humour is crass -it's oh-so-hilarious to rob young women of the ability to have kids. The move of suddenly turning overtly serious doesn't work neither do the puns. The slapstick humour is only exhausting and not engaging one bit.  Of the cast, the one who occasionally manages to pull off the ridiculousness is Akshay Kumar. It isn't a good sign at all that for a film that proclaims to be a comedy that the audience spends most of it in pin-drop silence.
